mSBLEx-y6.memHandModelNotes: Any natural grasslands do not need to conform to landforms.  Only forest types, pasture, clear cut and utility lines should be restricted by landforms.

references.B88JON01USGP: Jones, J. Knox Jr., and Elmer C. Birney. 1988. Handbook of mammals of the north-central states. University of Minnesota Press. Minneapolis. 346 Pages.
references.A83LIN01NAUS: Linzey, A.V. 1983. SYNAPTOMYS COOPERI. MAMMALIAN SPECIES. AMERICAN SOC. OF MAMMALOGISTS. 210:1-5.
references.B79HAM01NAUS: Hamilton, William J., Jr., and John O. Whitaker, Jr. 1979. Mammals of the eastern United States. Cornell Univ. Press, Ithaca, New York. 346 pp.
references.B77GOD01NAUS: Godin, A.J. 1977. Wild Mammals of New England. Johns Hopkins University Press, Baltimore. 304 pp.
references.B81SCH01NAUS: Schwartz, Charles W., and Elizabeth R. Schwartz. 1981. The Wild mammals of Missouri (2nd Ed.). Univ. of Missouri Press and Missouri Conserv. Dept., Columbia, MO. 356 p.
references.B83BAK01NAUS: Baker, Rollin H. 1983. Michigan mammals. Michigan State University Press. 642 pp.
references.A91HAN02NAUS: Handley, C. O., Jr. 1991. Mammals. Pages 539-616 in K. Terwilliger, coordinator. Virginia's endangered species:proceedings of a symposium. McDonald and Woodward Publishing Company, Blacksburg, Virginia.
references.B71LIN01HQUS: Linzey, Alicia V., & Donald W. Linzey. 1971. Mammals of the Great Smoky Mountains National Park. The University of Tennessee Press, Knoxville, Tennessee. 114 p.
references.A81LIN01NAUS: Linzey, A.V. 1981. Patterns of coexistence in MICROTUS PENNSYLVANICUS and SYNAPTOMYS COOPERI. Virginia Poly. Inst.and State Univ., unpubl. Ph.D. dissertation, 97 pp.
references.B81HAL01NAUS: Hall, E. R. 1981. The Mammals of North America. Second edition. 2 Volumes. John Wiley and Sons, New York, New York. 1181 p.
references.B59CON01NAUS: Conner, P. F. 1959. The bog lemming SYNAPTOMYS COOPERI in southern New Jersey. Publ. Mus. Michigan State Univ., Biol. Ser. 1(5):161-248.
references.A90CLA01NAUS: Clark, B. K., and D. W. Kaufman. 1990. Short-term responses of small mammals to experimental fire in tallgrass prairie. Can. J. Zool. 68:2450-2454.
references.A83LIN01USGP: Linzey, A. 1983. Mammalian Species: Synaptomys cooperi. American Society of Mammalogists. 210:1-5.
references.B98WHI01NCGP: Whitaker, J.O. Jr. and W.J. Hamilton, Jr. 1998.  Mammals of the eastern United States. Cornell Univ. Press, Ithaca, New York. 583 pp.

references.N82LEE01NAUS: Lee, D. S., L. B. Funderburg Jr., and M. K. Clark. 1982. A distributional survey of North Carolina mammals. Occasional Papers of the North Carolina Biological Survey, No. 1982-10. North Carolina State. Mus. Nat. Hist., Raleigh, North Carolina. 72 pp.
references.B85WEB01NAUS: Webster, W. D., J. F. Parnell and W. C. Biggs Jr. 1985. Mammals of the Carolinas, Virginia, and Maryland. The University of North Carolina Press, Chapel Hill, NC.
references.B88SAU01USGP: Saunders, D. A. 1988. Adirondack Mammals. State University of New York, College of Environmental Science and Forestry. 216pp.
references.B27HOW01NAUS: Howell, A. H. 1927. Revision of the American lemming mice (genus Synaptomys). North American Fauna 50:1-38.

habitat_description: The Southern Bog Lemming (Synaptomys cooperi) prefers bog, fen, marsh and wet meadow conditions with thick cover of grasses, sedges, or shrubs throughout its range (Whitaker and Hamilton 1998, Jones Jr. and Birney 1988). However, it will use a variety of open habitats, including dry grassy hillsides, tall grass fields, grassy areas interspersed with short-tree and shrubby growth, canebrakes, grassy clearings in woods, orchards and forest edges adjacent to meadows and old fields (Webster et al. 1985, Whitaker and Hamilton 1998). Green, succulent monocot grasses and sedges are a consistent and perhaps critical component of habitat (Whitaker and Hamilton 1998). It makes its den under mats of grass and sphagnum, in brushy thickets and in areas of thick leaf mold and humus. Burrow-like runways through the dense grass are similar to those made by species of in the genus Microtus.  There has been some evidence that Synaptomys only occurs where it is not excluded by Microtus species (Linzey 1983).  In upland settings, it may use open grassy areas as well as mesic, partially open to closed conifer, deciduous and mixed forests with a thick humus layer (Webster et al. 1985, Whitaker and Hamilton 1998). However, in drier forests of the New Jersey Pine Barrens, sphagnum bogs with tall grasses and sedges are the principal habitat (Whitaker and Hamilton 1998). Occupation of drier habitat may result when populations get too large to exist solely in more mesic habitat (Jones. and Birney 1988).  It is not restricted to bogs in Kansas; it also inhabits plant communities with thick, matted ground cover with high overhead vegetation in forests and grasslands, and their distribution is centered around springs, damp to wet grasslands, and marshes (Kansas Mammal Atlas 2015).  In the prairie and Great Lakes regions, it inhabits grasslands and possibly areas with shrubs (Linzey 1983).  Most captures in the East are associated with sphagnum bogs or heavily forested areas (Linzey 1983).  In the southern Appalachians, it is found in bogs, dry broomsedge fields, pastures, grassy openings in woods, power-line rights-of-way, clearcuts, and in rocky areas of spruce forests (Linzey 1983). In Missouri, it prefers heavy stands of bluegrass in low, moist locations, but also inhabits swamps, bogs, and damp woods with leaf litter (Schwartz and Schwartz 2001).  In Adirondacks, this species is known to occur between 244-1341 m in elevation (Saunders 1988).  It is restricted to relatively high elevations in the southern Appalachians (Linzey 1983).  N. Tarr, 29June2015.
